title: Corporate Tax Reform and the Cost of Bank Loans Evidence from the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act
affiliations: Macquarie University, Macquarie Business School, University of Sydney Business School, The University of Sydney - Discipline of Finance, affiliation not provided to SSRN and The University of Sydney - Business School

detail.title: Corporate Tax Reform and the Cost of Bank Loans Evidence from the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act
detail.abstract: This paper examines how the 2017 U.S. Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (TCJA)—a landmark corporate tax reform—affected the pricing and structure of syndicated bank loans. Using a difference-in-differences approach, we compare U.S. firms, which were directly exposed to the reform, with a matched sample of non-U.S. firms around the TCJA’s enactment. We find that U.S. borrowers experienced a significant reduction in loan spreads following the reform, consistent with lenders updating their expectations of improved firm cash flowsand creditworthiness. The decline in loanspreadsis morepronouncedamong firms with greater foreign exposure, higher tax savings, and tighter ex ante financial constraints. Additionally, we document adjustments in U.S. corporate borrowers’ non-pricing loan terms, including a higher likelihood of covenant-lite provisions and a reduced incidence of collateral and performance pricing requirements. Overall, our findings highlight the importance of corporate tax policy in shaping financial contracting in private credit markets.

title: The Power of Autonomy: Self-Selected Goals Outperform Assigned Goals in Reducing Mobile Phone Usage
affiliations: Indian Institute of Management Udaipur, INSEAD, Fundación Instituto de Empresa, S.L. - IE Business School and Indian School of Business

detail.title: The Power of Autonomy: Self-Selected Goals Outperform Assigned Goals in Reducing Mobile Phone Usage
detail.abstract: Behavior change interventions often involve experimenter-assigned goals. We conducted a randomized controlled trial to test whether self-selected goals are more effective than assigned goals in reducing mobile phone usage. Participants were randomly assigned to one of three conditions: a self-selected goal group (choosing a 10%, 20%, or 30% daily reduction from baseline), an assigned goal group (assigned a 14% reduction, matching the average chosen by the self-selected group), or a no-goal control. Despite identical average goals and incentives, participants in the self-selected condition reduced their mobile phone usage by 73% more and achieved their goals 11.3% more frequently than those in the assigned group. By the end of the 5-week intervention, participants in the self-selected condition showed lower depression scores (PHQ-9), anxiety scores (GAD-7), and perceived addiction levels. In contrast, participants in the assigned and no-goal control conditions showed no significant improvements in mental health or perceived addiction. These findings highlight the power of autonomy in goal-setting, suggesting that enabling individuals to set their own targets can enhance engagement, performance, and well-being in digital behavior change interventions.

title: The Reimaged NHS for the AI Era: The Evolution of the UK’s Healthcare in the Post-Digital Era
affiliations: University of South Wales

detail.title: The Reimaged NHS for the AI Era: The Evolution of the UK’s Healthcare in the Post-Digital Era
detail.abstract: The UK’s NHS stands at a critical juncture as it transitions into the AI Era, with Artificial Intelligence (AI) poised to drive profound organisational transformation. Despite years of digitalisation efforts, the NHS has largely failed to overhaul entrenched, outdated practices dating back to its inception in 1948. Instead, it has applied superficial technological upgrades without fundamentally rethinking healthcare delivery for the post-digital era. The next decade presents a key opportunity to embrace AI not just as a new tool, but as a catalyst for comprehensive, systemic change—redefining workflows, roles, data connectivity, and care models to create an integrated, intelligent health and wellness service. Achieving this shift requires breaking down legacy silos, encouraging innovation, adopting new skills, and implementing AI ethically and responsibly. As the NHS pivots from focusing solely on treating illness to an emphasis on prevention and community care, it will need a data-driven culture to support AI-enabled empowerment for both patients and staff. Realising this vision will require a fundamental change in mindset and governance to unlock AI’s full potential in delivering sustainable healthcare innovation, operational efficiency, and better patient outcomes.

title: Data Versus Information Sales under Financial Constraints
affiliations: University of Wisconsin School of Business, Stanford University - Stanford Graduate School of Business and University of Rochester - Simon Business School

detail.title: Data Versus Information Sales under Financial Constraints
detail.abstract: We study a dynamic problem of selling data without commitment to a budget-constrained receiver. The sender has access to a data-generating process, informative about a fundamental state, and can sell it either as granular observations (raw data) or summary statistics (information). Properly designed, such statistics ensure the residual uncertainty declines predictably along with the receiver’s budget, supporting efficiency under gradual information sales. In contrast, selling raw data poses a risk that future observations increase residual uncertainty, exceeding the receiver’s remaining budget. Consequently, selling data is inefficient if the fundamental is discrete and requires excess budget if the fundamental is non-Gaussian.

title: ECB Interest Rate Forecasting under High Inflation Pressures
affiliations: CNP Assurances

detail.title: ECB Interest Rate Forecasting under High Inflation Pressures
detail.abstract: From its foundation the European Central Bank has gradually made its monetary policy strategy more transparent, providing detailed rationale for each board decision and announcing possible short-term future actions. This has helped the market to develop expectations closely aligned with monetary policy decisions. In this paper we propose a linear interest rate forecasting model for the euro area based on the term structure of EURIBOR rates that closely approximates changes in the ECB main refinancing operations interest rate during the recent monetary tightening (July '22-September '23). We observe how under high inflation pressures the model can overperform the market expectations in tackling the ECB's policy decisions, showing its predictive effectiveness under unconventional policy monetary phases.

title: Do Family Trusts Promote Founders’ R&D in Family Firms?
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and Capital University of Economics and Business

detail.title: Do Family Trusts Promote Founders’ R&D in Family Firms?
detail.abstract: This study examines the impact of family trusts on founders’ R&D investment in family firms, addressing a critical gap in understanding how legal wealth arrangements shape long-term strategic decisions. Using a sample of Hong Kong-listed family firms from 2010 to 2021, we find that establishing family trusts significantly increases corporate R&D investment, a result robust to instrumental variable (IV) tests and placebo tests. Mechanism analyses reveal that this positive effect is amplified under higher succession uncertainty and greater financial constraints. By overcoming data limitations through a hybrid approach of machine learning and manual validation, this study integrates legal institutional design with corporate innovation theory, advancing research on family firm governance and long-term investment behavior.

title: Legal Issues of Financial Support for the Creation of High-Tech Industries with the Participation of Scientific Institutions in Ukraine

detail.title: Legal Issues of Financial Support for the Creation of High-Tech Industries with the Participation of Scientific Institutions in Ukraine
detail.abstract: Taking into account the fact that a large part of the industrial and agricultural complex of Ukraine has been destroyed as a result of military operations, the transformation of the economy of our state is extremely important. It has been established that the key driver of economic growth of any state is high-tech production. An important step for Ukraine today and in the postwar period is the reorientation of the economy from raw materials to high-tech. The Procedure for providing financial support for the creation of high-tech industries with the participation of higher education institutions and scientific institutions on the terms of co-financing, the project of which is proposed by the Ministry of Education and Science of Ukraine, is intended to a certain extent to solve the specified tasks. The purpose of this article is to analyze the draft Resolution of the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine "On approval of the Procedure for providing financial support for the creation of high-tech industries with the participation of higher educational institutions and scientific institutions on the terms of co-financing". In addition, the goal is to establish advantages, as well as contradictions, shortcomings of the specified project and provide relevant proposals for its improvement, applying general scientific and special scientific methods.

title: Reform, Repeal, Replace: A Case Study of Policy Whiplash in New Zealand’s Health Sector
affiliations: Victoria University of Wellington - Te Herenga Waka

detail.title: Reform, Repeal, Replace: A Case Study of Policy Whiplash in New Zealand’s Health Sector

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author has previously been an advisor to PHARMAC, is a member of multiple medical professional organisations such as the Royal Australasian College of Physicians (RACP) and Royal Australasian College of Medical Administrators (RACMA). The author submitted to parliament on the Medicines Amendment Bill, in relation to section 19 and use of unapproved medicines by paramedic.

detail.abstract:
Aims: For over a decade, New Zealand pursued a comprehensive reform of its outdated medicines legislation, culminating in the passage of the Therapeutic Products Act (TPA) in 2023. In a stark policy reversal, the Act was repealed by a new government in 2024. This study provides an analysis of this policy cycle to understand the drivers of the reform, its subsequent repeal, and the implications for future health policy.

Methods: We conducted a qualitative historical documentary analysis of 24 key government and stakeholder documents, including legislation, regulations, cabinet papers, and select committee reports with their submissions. We employed a Framework Method for a systematic thematic analysis of the corpus to map and interpret the policy narratives.

Results: The impetus for the TPA was a consensus that the Medicines Act 1981 and its associated regulations from 1984 and 1985 were "no longer fit for purpose. " The repeal was driven by an ideological shift, reframing the TPA as an unacceptable "regulatory burden. " This has tangible consequences, including the loss of a pre-market approval framework for medical devices and the erasure of legislative provisions designed to protect and recognise Rongoā Māori (traditional Māori healing).

Conclusion: The TPA policy cycle is a powerful case study in the fragility of evidence-based health reform. It demonstrates that without a durable, cross-party political consensus, long-term policy projects are highly vulnerable to being dismantled by short-term shifts in political ideology.

title: The Coevolution of Routines and IT Systems in IT-enabled Organizational Transformation as an Instance of Digital Transformation: A Social Constructivist Perspective

detail.title: The Coevolution of Routines and IT Systems in IT-enabled Organizational Transformation as an Instance of Digital Transformation: A Social Constructivist Perspective

publicationDetails.detailsText: Australasian Journal of Information Systems, volume 25, 2021[10.3127/ajis.v25i0.2855]

detail.abstract: This paper proposes a conceptual framework to study the phenomenon of IT-enabled Organizational Transformation (IT-enabled OT) as a coevolution process of organizational routines and a new IT system. The framework's objective is to understand IT-enabled OT in a holistic and integrated manner by investigating how actors perceive, interpret, appropriate, and enact, the new IT system in their work routines as well as how they align the new system and these routines with the social order and structures of the organization. It allows the examination of the reciprocal interactions between different aspects of organizational routines and a new IT system to enhance the understanding of how change unfolds in an organization during the implementation, the adoption, use, and adaptation of a new IT system. We illustrate the scope, the analytic and conceptual strength of the framework with a number of examples from the literature and, lastly, discuss its ontological positioning. The paper concludes with a call for further research to empirically validate and refine the proposed framework.

title: Digital Taxation and SME Sustainability in Nigeria: Evaluating the Role of E-Tax Systems in Enhancing Compliance and Financial Performance

detail.title: Digital Taxation and SME Sustainability in Nigeria: Evaluating the Role of E-Tax Systems in Enhancing Compliance and Financial Performance
detail.abstract: This study examines the role of digital taxation in enhancing compliance and financial performance among Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) in Nigeria, with specific focus on Lagos, Kano, and Abuja. Using a mixed-methods research design, data were collected from 370 SMEs through structured questionnaires and semi-structured interviews with SME operators and Federal Inland Revenue Service (FIRS) officials. Descriptive statistics, correlation, and regression analyses were used to assess the relationship between digital taxation, tax compliance, and SME sustainability, while thematic analysis was applied to qualitative responses. The findings reveal that adoption of e-tax platforms such as TaxPro-Max and e-payment systems is high, though formal training participation remains moderate. Digital taxation shows a strong positive correlation with tax compliance (r = 0.692, p < 0.05) and significantly influences financial performance, explaining 37.3% of its variation. Tax incentives were found to significantly moderate the relationship between digital taxation and SME sustainability. Qualitative insights indicate benefits such as time savings and transparency, alongside challenges related to internet infrastructure, cybersecurity, and technical support. The study concludes that digital taxation is a critical tool for improving SME compliance and financial performance in Nigeria. It recommends targeted taxpayer education, enhanced digital infrastructure, strengthened cybersecurity measures, and better management of tax incentives to maximize the benefits of e-tax systems.

title: Politics will Tear us Apart, Again: Geopolitical Risk, Fragmentation, and Capital Flows
affiliations: Bank of Italy

detail.title: Politics will Tear us Apart, Again: Geopolitical Risk, Fragmentation, and Capital Flows
detail.abstract: This review summarizes empirical research on the impact of geopolitical risk and financial fragmentation on cross-border capital flows. It distinguishes between event-driven geopolitical risk and structural political divides, showing that both influence international investment through retrenchment and alignment-based reallocation. Using gravity models, the literature documents a growing role of political distance in shaping foreign direct investment and portfolio flows, particularly in emerging markets, strategic sectors, and in the euro area since the invasion of Ukraine. Open questions include the macroeconomic consequences of financial fragmentation, its impact on the global financial cycle, and implications for the role of reserve currencies.

title: Health-System Reform and Performance Against National Targets in New Zealand: A 15-Year Interrupted Time-Series Analysis
affiliations: Victoria University of Wellington - Te Herenga Waka, Bond Business School and Bond University

detail.title: Health-System Reform and Performance Against National Targets in New Zealand: A 15-Year Interrupted Time-Series Analysis

declarations.declarationOfInterest: All authors declare no relevant financial relationships. DM and SS are employed by ambulance services.

detail.abstract:
Background: New Zealand's publicly funded health system has undergone significant reorganizations, yet persistent geographic and socioeconomic inequities remain. The 2022 Pae Ora (Healthy Futures) Act centralized health services, replacing 20 district health boards with a single national entity, Health New Zealand, and establishing a dedicated Māori Health Authority. In 2024 a new government reinstated five national performance targets and abolished the Māori Health Authority. How services have performed in this context is an important question which this study reports on. 

Methods: We conducted a retrospective interrupted time-series study using quarterly data from Q1 2010 to Q3 2024 for four national targets: emergency department stays, faster cancer treatment, first specialist assessments, and elective surgery. Data covered national, regional, and 20 legacy district series. We employed multilevel segmented regression to quantify trends and assess the causal effects of key policy milestones, including the announcement (April 2021) and implementation (July 2022) of Pae Ora reforms, and the reinstatement of national targets (July 2024). Vector Autoregression (VAR) models were used for multivariate forecasting, and a screening-level value-of-information (VOI) analysis estimated the decision value of moving from quarterly to monthly performance reporting. 

Findings: National performance across all targets showed a steady decline from 2016, accelerating sharply after the July 2022 centralization. Comprehensive Interrupted Time Series analysis across 80 unique time series revealed heterogeneous impacts, with some areas experiencing immediate drops or trend shifts, though not uniformly significant. Regional analysis highlighted disparities in reform effects. VAR models, accounting for interdependencies between measures, significantly outperformed univariate ARIMA models and a Grand Means Forecaster in forecasting accuracy (e.g., average MAE of 0.0214 for VAR vs. 0.0502 for ARIMA). All VOI scenarios indicated negative expected net benefit for switching to monthly reporting, with the largest Expected Value of Perfect Information (EVPI) being 16,500 resource units. 

Interpretation: The 2022 centralization appears to have accelerated pre-existing deterioration in service timeliness and exacerbated local inequities. This indicates that policymakers, in New Zealand and elsewhere, should carefully consider the impact on service delivery performance before embarking on major reforms. Quarterly monitoring remains a cost-effective approach, as monthly reporting offers only marginal additional information. To improve performance and address inequities, future policy should prioritize equity-weighted targets and district-tailored support.
